oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McKenzie Depot: history and property description
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 85 E. Bruce St., McKenzie, Carroll Co., TN

A history and description of the McKenzie Depot, its historical significance, and property description. Document is titled "Nashville, Chattanooga, and St. Louis Railway Passenger Station, Carroll Co., TN" and is an excerpt from a longer document.

The McKenzie Depot is a passenger station of the Nashville, Chattanooga, and St. Louis Railway (NC&St.L). It is an example of the "combination depot," combining two passenger waiting rooms, freight area, and ticket office within one building. The town of McKenzie, organized and platted in 1865, formed because of the intersection between two railroad lines. These lines were the NC&St.L and the Louisville and Nashville Railway. The McKenzie Depot dates to 1926, and the last passenger train stopped in McKenzie in 1970. After the demolition of a NC&St.L depot in Milan in 1993, the McKenzie Depot became the only extant Renaissance Revival styled passenger station in West Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Railroad stations -- Tennessee
